name: Black-tailed Prairie Dog
description: It’s stocky, with a rounded head and small, round ear flaps. The tail tip is black. Its brown fur has white-tipped hairs in summer and black-tipped in winter.
spread_note: From southwestern Canada to northern Mexico
image_alt: Black-tailed Prairie Dog, photo: Barbara Herza
proportions: Body length 28–33 cm; tail length 7.5–10.5 cm; shoulder height 8 cm; weight 0.9–1.5 kg
attractions: As their name suggests, prairie dogs inhabit North America’s grassy prairies, where they build vast underground towns often shared with other species, from snakes to black-footed ferrets. They’re highly social; though each family digs its own burrow system, these are interconnected. When a group grows too large for its home, the young stay in the original burrows, while experienced adults colonize nearby areas. Prairie dogs are diurnal. In their colonies, several always stand guard while others go about their tasks, warning of danger with a loud, barking call.
breeding: We’ve kept prairie dogs since 2000, with a brief break from late 2010 to mid-2011 when they moved from enclosures in the upper zoo to their current exhibit in the lower area.
